title: Getting Started with Turkish Banking Data
text: rbrsa package facilitates programmatic access Turkish banking sector data Turkish Banking Regulation Supervision Agency (BRSA, known BDDK Turkish). package provides R users clean interface fetch monthly quarterly banking statistics, financial reports, sectoral indicators directly BRSA’s official APIs. vignette demonstrates complete workflow: discovering available data fetching performing basic analysis. key features - Direct API access BRSA monthly bulletins (17 financial tables) - Quarterly Finturk data city-level granularity (7 tables, 82 cities including ‘HEPSİ’ cities) - Consistent parameter interface data sources - Built-metadata tables, banking groups, cities - Multiple export formats: RDS, CSV, Excel via save_data() - Returns base R data frames ready analysis

title: Getting Started with Turkish Banking Data
code: # Install from CRAN install.packages("rbrsa")  # Or install the development version from GitHub # install.packages("pak") pak.::pkg_install("obakis/rbrsa") # Load the package library(rbrsa)

title: Getting Started with Turkish Banking Data
text: requesting data, ’s useful explore tables banking groups available BDDK’s two main portals. portals official sources, organize data differently: Monthly Bulletin Portal provides high-level, summary reports designed general consumption quick overviews monthly trends without geographic coverage. Finturk Data System provides granular, detailed data, including statistics broken province, whereas standard Monthly Bulletin offers national-level aggregates. Important note: Currently, single grup_kod can specified per request. underlying BDDK API supports multiple grup_kod codes, functionality added future version.

title: Getting Started with Turkish Banking Data
text: Let’s fetch “Table 4: Consumer Loans” public banks (grup_kod = 10006) January 2020 December 2020. Let’s compare “Consumer Loans - Housing” “Consumer Loans - Personal Finance” time.
code: my_dat <- fetch_bddk(   start_year = 2020,   start_month = 1,   end_year = 2020,   end_month = 12,   table_no = 4,   grup_kod = 10001,   verbose=TRUE ) #> Fetching table 4 for 12 months: 2020-01 to 2020-12 #> [1/12] 2020-01... 41 rows #> [2/12] 2020-02... 41 rows #> [3/12] 2020-03... 41 rows #> [4/12] 2020-04... 41 rows #> [5/12] 2020-05... 41 rows #> [6/12] 2020-06... 41 rows #> [7/12] 2020-07... 41 rows #> [8/12] 2020-08... 41 rows #> [9/12] 2020-09... 41 rows #> [10/12] 2020-10... 41 rows #> [11/12] 2020-11... 41 rows #> [12/12] 2020-12... 41 rows # Examine the structure of the returned data cat("Dimensions:", dim(my_dat), "\n") #> Dimensions: 492 10 colnames(my_dat) #>  [1] "group_name" "BasitSira"  "Ad"         "BasitFont"  "TRY"        #>  [6] "FX"         "Total"      "grup_kod"   "period"     "currency" head(my_dat) #>       group_name BasitSira                                    Ad BasitFont #> 1 Banking Sector         1                Consumer Loans (2+3+4)      bold #> 2 Banking Sector         2              Consumer Loans - Housing           #> 3 Banking Sector         3              Consumer Loans - Vehicle           #> 4 Banking Sector         4     Consumer Loans - Personal Finance           #> 5 Banking Sector         5   Consumer Loans - Fx Indexed (6+7+8)      bold #> 6 Banking Sector         6 Consumer Loans - Housing (Fx Indexed)           #>      TRY FX  Total grup_kod  period currency #> 1 480482 82 480564    10001 2020-01       TL #> 2 202648 46 202694    10001 2020-01       TL #> 3   6979  0   6979    10001 2020-01       TL #> 4 270855 36 270892    10001 2020-01       TL #> 5     65  0     65    10001 2020-01       TL #> 6     55  0     55    10001 2020-01       TL ## To save the results: # temp_file <- tempfile() # filename should be without extension # save_data(my_dat, temp_file, format = "csv") library(dplyr) library(ggplot2) colnames(my_dat) #>  [1] "group_name" "BasitSira"  "Ad"         "BasitFont"  "TRY"        #>  [6] "FX"         "Total"      "grup_kod"   "period"     "currency" cols = c("Consumer Loans - Housing","Consumer Loans - Personal Finance") p = my_dat |>   select(Ad,TRY,period) |>   filter(Ad %in% cols) |>   mutate(date=as.Date(paste0(period, "-01"))) |>   ggplot(aes(x=date, y=TRY, color=Ad, group=Ad, shape=Ad)) +   geom_line(linewidth = 1) +   geom_point(size = 2.4, alpha = 0.7) +   scale_x_date(     date_breaks = "2 months",      # Show tick every 3 months     date_labels = "%b %Y",         # Format as "Jan 2020"     expand = c(0.01, 0)           # Reduce padding   ) +   scale_y_continuous(     labels = scales::comma       # Format numbers with commas   ) +   labs(     title = "Consumer Loans Trends, Jan 2020-Dec 2020 (TRY)",     subtitle = "Monthly data for Housing vs Personal Finance loans",     x = "",     y = ""   ) +   theme_minimal() + theme(     legend.position = "bottom",  # This moves the legend to the bottom     axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1),     plot.title = element_text(face = "bold", size = 14),   ) p

[11] "Diğer Mevduat (DTH)"     "Toplam Mevduat"          #> [13] "plaka"                   "period"                  #> [15] "table_no" head(my_dat2) #>   grup_kod  Yıl Ay         il_adi   Grup 1 2023-03        2 #> 2            3422143              711127       18322782     2 2023-03        2 #> 3            5476164             1742209       33400954     3 2023-03        2 #> 4 11413002     5 2023-03        2 ## To save the results: # temp_file <- tempfile() # filename should be without extension # save_data(my_dat, temp_file, format = "csv") sel_cities =c("ADANA","MALATYA","MUĞLA","KAYSERİ") cols = c("il_adi", "period","Toplam Mevduat") lookup <- c(city="il_adi", deposit="Toplam Mevduat") p2 = my_dat2[,cols] |>   rename(all_of(lookup)) |>   mutate(date=as.Date(paste0(period, "-01"))) |>   mutate(.by=period, sh = 100*deposit/sum(deposit, na.rm=TRUE)) |>   filter( city %in% sel_cities) |>     ggplot(aes(x=date, y=sh, color=city, group=city, shape=city)) +   geom_line(linewidth = 1) +   geom_point(size = 2.4, alpha = 0.7) +   scale_x_date(     date_breaks = "3 months",      # Show tick every 3 months     date_labels = "%b %Y", title: Getting Started with Turkish Banking Data
text: save_data() function allows export results various formats use tools.
code: # Save to different formats. file name must be without extension save_data(my_dat, "filename_you_prefer", format = "csv") save_data(my_dat, "filename_you_prefer", format = "rds") save_data(my_dat, "filename_you_prefer", format = "xlsx")  # Using tempfile() for examples (as in README) temp_file <- tempfile() save_data(my_dat, temp_file, format = "csv") cat("Data saved to:", temp_file, "\n")

title: Fetch Turkish Banking Sector Data from the Turkish Banking Regulation and Supervision Agency
text: R package programmatic access Turkish banking sector data Turkish Banking Regulation Supervision Agency (BRSA, known BDDK Turkish). package provides R users clean interface fetch monthly quarterly banking statistics, financial reports, sectoral indicators directly BRSA’s official APIs.

title: Fetch Turkish Banking Sector Data from the Turkish Banking Regulation and Supervision Agency
text: Direct API access BRSA monthly bulletins (17 financial tables) Quarterly Finturk data city-level granularity (7 tables, 82 cities including ‘HEPSİ’ cities) Consistent parameter interface data sources Built-metadata tables, banking groups, provinces Multiple export formats: RDS, CSV, Excel via save_data() Returns base R data frames ready analysis

title: Fetch Turkish Banking Sector Data from the Turkish Banking Regulation and Supervision Agency
text: Lightweight Authentic: packages providing access BDDK data (like bddkR) also fetch data programmatically, add heavy translation layer —maintaining manual configuration files map Turkish column names categorical values English. provides user convenience high maintenance cost. rbrsa takes different path. interacts directly API uses data returns minimal alteration: Monthly Bulletin, uses official English column names labels provided API lang = "en" set. Finturk dataset, API provides data Turkish, returns authentic Turkish names. deliberate choice. avoiding separate translation file, rbrsa eliminates major maintenance burden, aiming adapt instantly API changes. way, data see exactly official source provides.

title: Fetch Turkish Banking Sector Data from the Turkish Banking Regulation and Supervision Agency
text: bddkR (R): Uses manual configuration translations column mappings provides access Monthly Bulletin. bddk (Python): Provides similar functionality Python users constraints bddkR. bddkdata (Python): Provides similar functionality Python/pandas users constraints bddkR. pybrsa (Python, forthcoming): Python companion package consistent API.

code: install.packages("rbrsa") #install.packages("pak") pak::pkg_install("obakis/rbrsa")

title: Fetch Turkish Banking Sector Data from the Turkish Banking Regulation and Supervision Agency
text: Full package documentation function references available : https://obakis.github.io/rbrsa/ rbrsa package retrieves tables two distinct publication portalsmaintained Turkish Banking Regulation Supervision Agency (BDDK). portals official sources, organize data differently: Monthly Bulletin Portal provides high-level, summary reports designed general consumption quick overviews monthly trends without geographic coverage. Finturk Data System provides granular, detailed data, including statistics broken province, whereas standard Monthly Bulletin offers national-level aggregates.
code: library(rbrsa) ## Explore available tables list_tables("bddk") # list_tables("bddk","tr") list_tables("finturk")  # list_tables("finturk", "tr") list_groups("bddk")   list_groups("bddk","tr")   list_groups("finturk")  ## Monthly data (Table 15: Ratios) data <- fetch_bddk(2024, 1, 2024, 3, table_no = 15, grup_kod = 10001)  ## Quarterly Finturk data q_data <- fetch_finturk(2024, 3, 2024, 9, table_no = 1, grup_kod = 10007)  ## Save results temp_file <- tempfile() # filename should be without extension save_data(q_data, temp_file, format = "csv")

what: Fetch multiple period table from BDDK website — fetch_bddk
title: Fetch multiple period table from BDDK website — fetch_bddk
text: Fetches BDDK data range months calling fetch_bddk1 iteratively.

title: Fetch multiple period table from BDDK website — fetch_bddk
code: fetch_bddk(   start_year,   start_month,   end_year,   end_month,   table_no,   grup_kod = 10001,   currency = "TL",   lang = "en",   delay = 0.5,   verbose = TRUE )

title: Fetch multiple period table from BDDK website — fetch_bddk
text: start_year, end_year Starting/ending year (YYYY). start_month, end_month Starting/ending month (1-12). table_no Table number fetch (1-17). default. Use list_tables source = "bddk" see available options. grup_kod Group code (10001-10016). Default 10001. Use list_groups source = "bddk" see available options. currency Currency code ("TL" "USD"). Default "TL". lang Language ("en" "tr"). Default "en". delay Delay requests seconds. Default 0.5. verbose Print progress messages. Default TRUE.

title: Fetch multiple period table from BDDK website — fetch_bddk

title: Fetch Monthly Data from BDDK with Multiple Group Codes — fetch_bddk1

title: Fetch Monthly Data from BDDK with Multiple Group Codes — fetch_bddk1
code: fetch_bddk1(   year,   month,   table_no,   grup_kod = 10001,   currency = "TL",   lang = "en" )

title: Fetch Monthly Data from BDDK with Multiple Group Codes — fetch_bddk1
text: year Year 4-digit integer (YYYY). month Month integer (1-12). table_no Table number fetch (1-17). default. Use list_tables source = "bddk" see available options. grup_kod Group code (10001-10010). Default 10001. Use list_groups source = "bddk" see available options. currency Currency code ("TL" "USD"). Default "TL". lang Language ("en" "tr"). Default "en".

what: Fetch multiple period Finturk data — fetch_finturk
title: Fetch multiple period Finturk data — fetch_finturk
text: Fetches Finturk data range quarters calling fetch_finturk1 iteratively.

title: Fetch multiple period Finturk data — fetch_finturk
code: fetch_finturk(   start_year,   start_month,   end_year,   end_month,   table_no,   grup_kod = 10001,   il = 0,   delay = 0.5,   verbose = TRUE )

title: Fetch multiple period Finturk data — fetch_finturk
text: start_year, end_year Starting/ending year (YYYY). start_month, end_month Starting/ending month (3,6,9,12). table_no Table number fetch (1-7). default. Use list_tables source = "finturk" see available options. grup_kod Group code (10001-10007). Default 10001. Use list_groups source = "finturk" see available options. il plaka (license plate) number (0-81, 99). Default 0. delay Delay requests seconds. Default 0.5. verbose Print progress messages. Default TRUE.

title: Fetch multiple period Finturk data — fetch_finturk
text: Combined data frame "fetch_info" attribute.

title: Fetch multiple period Finturk data — fetch_finturk
code: # \donttest{   # Fetch multiple quarters   my_data <- fetch_finturk(2024, 3, 2024, 9, table_no = 1) #> Fetching table 1 for 3 quarterly periods: 2024-03 to 2024-09 #> [1/3] 2024-03... 82 rows #> [2/3] 2024-06... 82 rows #> [3/3] 2024-09... 82 rows # }

what: Fetch Quarterly Data from BDDK Finturk with Multiple Provinces — fetch_finturk1
title: Fetch Quarterly Data from BDDK Finturk with Multiple Provinces — fetch_finturk1
text: Retrieves quarterly banking data BDDK Finturk API specified group codes provinces. Supports multiple group codes province codes single request.

title: Fetch Quarterly Data from BDDK Finturk with Multiple Provinces — fetch_finturk1
code: fetch_finturk1(year, month, table_no, grup_kod = 10001, il = 0)

title: Fetch Quarterly Data from BDDK Finturk with Multiple Provinces — fetch_finturk1
text: year Year 4-digit integer (YYYY). month Month integer (3,6,9,12 quarterly data). table_no Table number fetch (1-7). default. grup_kod Group code (10001-1007). Default 10001. il plaka (license plate) number (0-81); 999 = Yurt Dışı. Default 0. 0=HEPSİ (Cities), 1=Adana, 6=Ankara, 34=İstanbul, 35=İzmir, etc. See list_cities full list.

title: Fetch Quarterly Data from BDDK Finturk with Multiple Provinces — fetch_finturk1
text: Data frame fetch_info attribute contains query details.

title: Fetch Quarterly Data from BDDK Finturk with Multiple Provinces — fetch_finturk1
text: Finturk API provides data quarter-ending months (March, June, September, December). Province codes follow Turkey's standard license plate numbering (1 = Adana, 6 = Ankara, 34 = İstanbul, etc.).

title: Fetch Quarterly Data from BDDK Finturk with Multiple Provinces — fetch_finturk1

title: rbrsa 0.2.0
text: Support multiple grup_kod code multiple provinces (il) fetch_finturk() Support multiple grup_kod code fetch_bddk() vignette “Getting Started Turkish Banking Data” provides introduction package’s main features.

title: rbrsa 0.1.0
text: Initial release core functionality Support 17 monthly BRSA tables Support 7 quarterly Finturk tables Built-metadata tables, groups, cities Export functions RDS, CSV, Excel formats
